abstract.p: Palestinian court in Nablus sentences Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, Islamic militant whom Israelis failed to capture in botched raid on West Bank house, to 12 years in prison (S)

block.p: In a speedy closed-door trial in Nablus this evening, a Palestinian state security court sentenced to 12 years an Islamic militant whom the Israelis failed to capture in a botched raid on a West Bank house last week.

The militant, Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, 33, a leader of the Hamas organization's military wing in the West Bank, was convicted of forming and arming a military cell that acted at cross-purposes with the Palestinian Authority, the Palestinian attorney general, Khalid al-Kidra, said.

The militant, Mahmoud Abu Hanoud, 33, a leader of the Hamas organization's military wing in the West Bank, was convicted of forming and arming a military cell that acted at cross-purposes with the Palestinian Authority, the Palestinian attorney general, Khalid al-Kidra, said.
Mr. Abu Hanoud has been wanted for years by Israeli authorities, who said he played a crucial role in terrorist attacks that killed at least 17.
The Palestinian court did not consider the Israeli charges.

Last weekend, an elite undercover unit of the Israeli Army staged a raid on his house without coordinating the operation with the Palestinian police. Three Israeli soldiers killed by fire from Israeli soldiers during the raid, the army said.
And Mr. Abu Hanoud, who was shot in the shoulder, escaped. He later turned himself in to the Palestinian authorities, who gave him a few days to recover before his trial.
